title: Body Image & Confidence
description: Explore how you feel about your body and how that affects intimacy.

questions.text: When it comes to feeling comfortable in my body during intimacy, I...
choices: Generally feel confident and at ease
Have moments of self-consciousness
Struggle with this more than I'd like
Am working on being kinder to myself

therapeutic.rationale: Body confidence during intimacy affects enjoyment and presence. Confident types are free to enjoy; moment-of-doubt types manage occasional insecurity; strugglers carry ongoing discomfort; workers are actively healing. This is deeply personal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The confident partner may not understand the struggler's experience; the struggler may envy their partner's ease. Be gentle with each other's body journeys.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared body confidence level creates mutual understanding of this vulnerable area.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about your body during intimacy? What would help you feel more at ease?

questions.text: What helps me feel confident and attractive is...
choices: Verbal affirmation from my partner
How my partner looks at me
Taking care of myself and feeling good
Feeling genuinely desired

therapeutic.rationale: Confidence sources vary. Verbal-needers want words; look-readers watch expressions; self-care types build internal confidence; desire-needers want to feel wanted. Knowing your partner's source helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sources mean providing different things. The verbal-needer may not feel affirmed by looks alone; the desire-needer may not feel affirmed by self-care compliments.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared confidence source makes affirming each other intuitive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel attractive and confident? Does your partner know how to help you feel this way?

questions.text: When I'm feeling self-conscious about my body, I'd want my partner to...
choices: Offer reassurance and affirmation
Not make a big deal of it
Create a judgment-free space
Be patient while I work through it

therapeutic.rationale: Support needs during body insecurity vary. Reassurance-seekers want active affirmation; low-key types want normalcy; judgment-free seekers want acceptance; patience-needers want time. Mismatched support backfires.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The reassurance-seeker may feel dismissed if their partner doesn't make a big deal; the low-key type may feel smothered by constant affirmation. Ask what helps.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched support needs make helping each other through body struggles intuitive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need from your partner when you're feeling self-conscious? What doesn't help?

questions.text: My view on aging and how it affects intimacy is...
choices: Bodies change—attraction can grow and deepen
I worry about it sometimes
I'm working on accepting my changing body
Connection matters more than appearance

therapeutic.rationale: Aging attitudes affect long-term intimacy. Growth-mindset types see deepening; worriers have anxiety; accepters are working toward peace; connection-focusers prioritize depth. These attitudes shape how intimacy evolves.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The worrier may need reassurance the growth-mindset partner doesn't think to give. Be explicit about your long-term attraction and commitment.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared aging attitude helps you face body changes together with similar outlooks.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about your body changing as you age? What do you need from your partner as this happens?

questions.text: The environment that helps me feel most comfortable being intimate is...
choices: Low lighting where I feel less exposed
Whatever feels natural—I'm not particular
One where I feel emotionally safe first
One where I know I'm desired

therapeutic.rationale: Environmental comfort needs vary. Low-light lovers manage exposure; natural-feelers are flexible; emotional-safety seekers need connection; desire-needers want to feel wanted. Setting matters more than we often discuss.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different environmental needs are easy to accommodate once known. The low-light lover may not realize their partner doesn't need it; share your preferences.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared environmental preferences make setting up for intimacy easier.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What environment helps you feel most comfortable being intimate? Have you shared this with your partner?
